Award.AbstractNarration: This research project is a study of global nuclear environmental history focused on North America, Europe, the former Soviet Union, and Far East. The PI will develop a cross national comparison of the environment in relation to military and civilian nuclear enterprises. In doing so, he will examine how understandings of the human-nature atom interface have changed since the dawn of the nuclear age. The project will produce a stand-alone global environmental history of the development of the nuclear enterprise in cross-national comparison that includes the conceptual, technological, socio-political and environmental impacts that have accompanied that development. The research takes place within the fields of history of science and technology, environmental history, and history of technology; results are to be disseminated as original research papers and a book manuscript pertinent to these areas. The PI also plans to disseminate results beyond scientific publications through editorials and through contact with various interested NGOs with interests in nuclear history, and through a dedicated webpage with links to extant and new research materials and teaching guides. <br/><br/>This research project will bring STS and environmental history methods to bear on the study of the nuclear world to enable better understanding of the rise and functioning of state-sponsored big science and technology for military and peaceful purposes. The PI will use recently available primary sources in English, French, Russian, Swedish, Korean and other languages. He will also make extensive use of published and archival documents and studies on the nature of human-nuclear interactions in the domain of nuclear science and technology for different groups, languages and ethnicities, and across geographic and climatic areas; as a result, this research will produce societally relevant outcomes in its analyses of the role of women, children, underrepresented minorities including indigenes in postwar nuclear worlds. This history is valuable because of the vast expanse of the nuclear enterprise, its transborder and international ramifications, and the nature and kinds of landscapes and peoples whose lives have been affected by peaceful and military programs â€“ and who have shaped its development. It will have the potential to contribute to policy debates about the costs, benefits and consequences of nuclear technologies over time, and to facilitate analysis of nuclear power as an effective way to address climate change in the twenty-first century.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Project Outcomes Report:

A Global Nuclear Environmental History

Paul Josephson, PI

Colby College, Waterville, ME 04901

NSF Contract 2020024.  January 2024

 

From the 1940s the global nuclear enterprise spread massively through over 2,000 weapons tests, the manufacture of 70,000 nuclear warheads, the construction of some 450 reactors at NPPs (nuclear power plants), with 50 reactors currently under construction, all at a total of many trillions of dollars. Nuclear power is the world's second largest source of low-carbon power and generates roughly 2.6 billion kw/hours of electricity annually. Thirty-two countries operate NPPs. Chinese, French, Soviet, British and American military planners sought vast land holdings, to them devoid of human habitation, preferably far from borders, or in colonial possessions, to exploit ore, erect enrichment plants, test weapons and open nuclear power stations. Now ten possess nuclear weapons.

Large scale nuclear systems have been reproduced in similar environments across the globe for both civilian and military projects. They occupy riverine, lake and ocean ecosystems, taking control of them through extravagant human, capital, and other resources as manifested in prospecting, uranium ore mining, fuel fabrication, weapons and nuclear power facilities, and the legal and policies provisions that enable their operation.

The project in the history of science and technology centered on a comparative environmental history of the nuclear age for all of these objects. It examined the contention that peaceful and military programs operated in separate spheres by looking at nuclear technologies in desert, Arctic, tropical, riverine, oceanic and other settings; and across the entire nuclear enterprise from uranium ore mining to fuel enrichment to fission in bombs, reactors and other applications. It considered the views of the environmental soundness of nuclear technologies among promoters, industrialists, financiers, and policy makers, engineers and laypeople, protestors, weapons test downwinders and indigenes. It focused primarily on nuclear programs in the northern hemisphere, from Canada and the United States to Sweden, Finland, France, Spain and the Baltic states; from the former Soviet Union, Ukraine and Russia, and such formerly socialist nuclear nations as Bulgaria, Lithuania, and the Czech Republic, to Korea, Japan and China; and from India to South Africa. It evaluated what we can learn from nuclear accidents, incidents and catastrophes.

In the end, project analysis showed that nuclear programs are not as environmentally as green as promoters claim, since this claim often ignores the military side of programs and also the vast quantities of waste that have accumulated. This finding suggests careful reexamination of the argument that nuclear power is a solution to global warming going forward without deal with waste and with increasing costs The findings of this project will enable policy makers, engineers, and citizens to make informed choices about future energy transitions and scenarios in the effort to build a low-carbon economy in which nuclear power production has a central position.

In addition to considering a variety of ecosystems, flora and fauna, this project generated a historical examination of nuclear human subject research. Since the beginning of the nuclear age millions of cubic meters and tons of radioactive materials have entered the ecosystems of the world.  Many of them are long-lived and toxic. They originated in military, industrial, power production, medical and agricultural settings, from mines and fuel fabrication facilities, and from nuclear weapons and fallout. They are taken up in plants and animals including in human beings, sometimes in fatal or carcinogenic, if minute quantities. They bioaccumulate. Over the decades the industry has pursued a variety of methods to handle low-, intermediate- and high-level radioactive waste (LLW, ILW, HLW), primarily through dumping and diluting, burying near surface, covering, enclosing, vitrifying and other methods of waste handling, and increasingly in an expensive and time consuming search for permanent safe storage, especially for HLW, including materials that will be hazardous for 100,000 years. Millions of people have been exposed to ionizing radiation as a result with still-being-evaluated health impacts.

Indeed, the costs of the effort to remediate the vast quantities of radioactive waste, the technical hurdles that remain, and the unwillingness of most local communities to offer their homes and business as cover for underground waste facilities suggest that it will be still another three or four generations before radioactive waste is stored properly, unfortunately at a cost of well over $1 trillion.

A Global Nuclear Environmental History examined scientific articles, films, memoirs, industry brochures and other publications, government documents, accident reports and archival materials in the effort to compile a complete environmental history of nuclear technologies.
